config.topic: What happened to research on automated visualization?
config.target_audience: researchers in the visualization community, they might be interested in both topic evolution and how people in the field shape the research (such as their interactions and key players)
config.domain_knowledge:
Regarding identification of automated visualization papers:

The following keywords are used to identify the automated visualization papers:
- automatic vis
- automated vis
- visualization recommendation
- mixed initiative
- mixed-initiative
- visualization generation
- vis generation
- agent

An example vega-lite filter:
test(/automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent/i, (datum.AuthorKeywords || '') + ' ' + (datum.Abstract || '') + ' ' + (datum.Title || '')) ? 'AutoVis' : 'Other'

report_outline.section_description: High-level synthesis: succinct answers to 'What happened to research on automated visualization?' — whether it grew, waned, or shifted focus — and the specific questions the report will answer.

content.text: Research on automated visualization (AutoVis) has not disappeared — it is active, concentrated, and has evolved rather than simply grown steadily. In our filtered vis-publication dataset nearly all identified records (80–83 of 83) match AutoVis keywords, with activity concentrated in a few venues (especially Vis, VAST, and InfoVis) and a notable peak in output around 2021. The field shows bursts of high-impact work (a small set of milestone papers with high citations and downloads) alongside a long tail of single-publication authors and many small collaborative groups. Important shifts are visible in topical emphasis (from early theoretical work toward recommendation, mixed-initiative systems, and more recently machine-learning driven approaches) and in the kinds of evaluation and deployment evidence authors report. This report will answer: How did AutoVis paper volume and venue distribution change over time? Which topics and methods rose or fell, and when? Who are the central people and institutions shaping the field and how do collaboration patterns evolve? Finally, what is the measured impact of AutoVis work, how reproducible and deployable is it, and which actions would best accelerate progress and reuse?

report_outline.section_description: Describe the vis-publication dataset and how automated-visualization (AutoVis) papers are identified (keyword-based filter using: automatic vis | automated vis | visualization recommendation | mixed initiative | mixed-initiative | visualization generation | vis generation | agent). Explain preprocessing, key attributes used (Year, Conference, Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords, AuthorNames, AuthorAffiliation, Citation counts), and planned analytic methods and visual encodings.

global_filter_state.description: Select all papers whose Title, Abstract, or AuthorKeywords mention terms used to identify automated-visualization research (case-insensitive). Returns all columns to support exploration over time; results are ordered by Year.
global_filter_state.sql_query:
SELECT *
FROM Papers
WHERE lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%automatic vis%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%automated vis%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization recommendation%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed initiative%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed-initiative%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization generation%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%vis generation%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%agent%'
ORDER BY Year ASC;

Decision rule for citation counts: preferred field(s) and fallback strategy (e.g., use CitationCount_CrossRef if present, otherwise AminerCitationCount; document merges and units)

content.text: The analysis uses a curated vis-publication dataset spanning 1995–2024 and leverages a keyword-based AutoVis filter to flag candidate papers. Papers are identified as AutoVis when their Title, Abstract, or AuthorKeywords contain any of the target terms: automatic vis, automated vis, visualization recommendation, mixed initiative / mixed-initiative, visualization generation / vis generation, or agent. Preprocessing included normalizing text for matching, converting Year to numeric, splitting and normalizing author and affiliation fields, and merging citation counts from CrossRef and Aminer. Key attributes used in analyses are Year, Conference, Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords, AuthorNames (and AuthorNames-Deduped), AuthorAffiliation, and citation/download fields (CitationCount_CrossRef, AminerCitationCount, Downloads_Xplore). Planned methods combine descriptive statistics, time-series and venue breakdowns, keyword frequency and co-occurrence analysis, topic modeling or embedding projections (UMAP/t-SNE) for semantic mapping, and network analysis for co-authorship structures; visual encodings include bars and lines for temporal and venue summaries, stacked/stream or small-multiple plots for shares, node-link layouts for collaboration networks, and scatter/LOESS plots for citation impact.

content.text: The two-panel visualization summarizes where AutoVis work appears and how its yearly volume changed. The first panel shows AutoVis paper counts by conference and makes clear that the bulk of records are concentrated in a small set of venues: Vis (about 45 papers), VAST (about 21), InfoVis (about 13), and SciVis (about 4). The second panel overlays an absolute-count bar chart with a line showing the AutoVis proportion per year; in this filtered dataset the AutoVis proportion is effectively 100% for most years because the dataset itself is focused on AutoVis candidates, but the absolute counts reveal important temporal structure — small early activity in the 1990s and 2000s, gradual increases in the 2010s, and a prominent peak of output in 2021 (16 papers). Interpreting these plots together highlights that recent growth in raw counts is driven by activity in the major venues (particularly Vis) rather than by a diffuse expansion across many new conferences.

content.text: The missingness and availability visualizations diagnose data quality and citation coverage important for downstream analyses. Core bibliographic fields (Title, Abstract, AuthorNames, AuthorNames-Deduped, and AuthorAffiliation) are complete in this dataset, which supports robust text-based classification and author-level analyses; AuthorKeywords are missing for a small fraction (~7%). Citation fields differ in coverage: CrossRef counts are present for all records (100%), while Aminer coverage is lower (~70%), and the two sources are highly correlated where both exist (Pearson ≈ 0.94). Author-name deduplication exists for many records but exact-string equality between raw and deduped names occurs in only about 39% of cases, so the recommendation is to use AuthorNames-Deduped when available and otherwise apply careful normalization (lowercasing, punctuation removal, splitting on separators) and to treat ambiguous mappings with manual review. Affiliation parsing heuristics (split on “;”, normalize institution tokens and country candidates) recover clear institutional leaders (e.g., Georgia Tech, Zhejiang University, Microsoft Research Asia, Tongji, University of Washington) but warrant normalization via fuzzy matching or a lookup table before reporting counts. For citation-based work prefer CrossRef if available and fall back to Aminer, documenting the chosen field and performing sensitivity checks.

report_outline.section_name: Temporal trends: volume and venue shifts
report_outline.section_description: Quantify how the number and share of AutoVis papers changed over time and across venues (InfoVis, VAST, SciVis, TVCG, etc.). Planned visuals: yearly line chart for absolute counts, stacked-area or streamgraph for AutoVis vs. other topics, per-conference small multiples, and milestone timeline of influential AutoVis papers (high-citation or awards). This section answers whether AutoVis grew, plateaued, or migrated across venues and years.

content.text: Temporal analysis shows that AutoVis activity has been episodic rather than a steadily accelerating phenomenon: the dataset records early isolated contributions in the 1990s and 2000s, more sustained activity in the 2010s, and a pronounced peak in 2021. Because this collection was pre-filtered to AutoVis candidates, the proportional share of AutoVis within the dataset is typically at or near 100%, so the most informative signal is absolute paper count by year and venue. Vis is the dominant home for AutoVis work across decades, VAST shows a notable rise, and InfoVis and SciVis host smaller but steady contributions. Overall the pattern is best described as a plateau with periodic bursts and recent intensification in specific venues rather than a broad migration across many new conferences.

content.text: The annual-count visualization contrasts AutoVis versus other categories and tracks AutoVis share by selected venues; in practice the dataset is heavily AutoVis-focused so the AutoVis share plot appears saturated. The year-by-year counts reveal the detailed rhythm: two early papers in 1995, scattered single papers in many years, and larger clusters of activity from 2014 onward, culminating in a 2021 spike of 16 AutoVis papers. Breaking this down by venue shows that much of the recent volume concentrates in Vis and that VAST increased its AutoVis activity over time. Interpreting these charts together indicates no wholesale venue abandonment or migration but rather renewed and concentrated interest at key conferences, with Vis remaining the primary platform.

content.text: The milestone timeline highlights influential AutoVis contributions and offers objective selection criteria for what counts as a milestone. Citation and download summaries show a long-tailed distribution (CrossRef citations mean ≈ 31, median 14, max 292; Downloads_Xplore mean ≈ 1,246, median 937), and combined scores that weight citations, downloads, and awards identify high-impact works such as Voyager (2015, ≈292 CrossRef cites), Draco (2018, ≈177 cites and a best-paper award), and the 2013 Design Space of Visualization Tasks (≈144 cites). Recommended rules for picking milestone papers are: include award winners, include papers above the 90th percentile on citations or downloads (e.g., CrossRef ≥ ~81), and prefer a compact top-N (8–12) by citation count while adding high-download or award outliers. The timeline thus balances objective bibliometrics and community-recognized impact when presenting the field’s turning points.

content.text: Topical mapping shows AutoVis shifting from foundational, theory-oriented work toward practical recommendation systems, mixed-initiative workflows, and automated generation aided by machine learning. Keyword analysis and co-occurrence patterns reveal that terms like visualization, visual analytics, and visualization recommendation appear most often; more recent years show growth in terms such as automatic visualization, reinforcement learning, and application-motivated visualization. Co-occurrence and Sankey-style transitions suggest that mixed-initiative approaches often intersect with temporal and application-driven problems, and that method categories (e.g., agent-based or ML-driven approaches) increasingly connect to concrete application domains. To capture these patterns robustly we recommend using AuthorKeywords as primary labels with Title/Abstract as fallbacks, applying normalization and alias mapping, and exploring topic modeling (LDA with k∈{6,8,10}) plus embedding projections (UMAP or t-SNE) and time-binned Sankeys to visualize method → domain transitions.

These trajectories indicate a field that is diversifying in technique (more ML and agent-like methods) and prioritizing actionable systems and recommendations over purely theoretical work.

content.text: The people and institution analysis shows a compact core of productive contributors surrounded by many single-publication authors: 311 distinct (deduped) authors in the set, 78% of whom appear with only one paper. Top individual contributors include Alex Endert (7 publications), Huamin Qu and Yingcai Wu (6 each), and Jeffrey Heer and Nan Cao (5 each). Institutional parsing identifies strong groups at Zhejiang University, Georgia Tech, Hong Kong UST, Adobe Research, and University of Washington among the most prolific affiliations, though affiliation normalization is imperfect and benefits from manual or external disambiguation. The co-authorship network is substantial (≈311 nodes, ≈895 edges), with high-degree and high-betweenness actors forming bridging roles; community structure increases in complexity over time, especially in the 2019–2021 window when node/edge counts and detected communities spike. These patterns point to a lively but concentrated collaboration ecosystem where a handful of labs and authors exert outsized influence.

Diagnostics show the full network contains about 311 nodes and 895 edges; a top-50 subgraph yields a small number of communities (≈7) that capture disciplinary or regional clusters. Author-name disambiguation is good but not perfect (315 normalized raw names vs. 311 deduped), so we recommend using AuthorNames-Deduped when available and flagging ambiguous mappings for manual inspection; for visualization, a focused subnet (top K by degree or publications, K≈50) is recommended to expose interpretable communities without overwhelming layout.

   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%automated vis%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization recommendation%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed initiative%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%mixed-initiative%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization generation%'
   OR lower(coalesce(AuthorKeywords, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Abstract, '') || ' ' || coalesce(Title, '')) LIKE '%vis generation%'

content.text: Impact metrics confirm a skewed landscape: a few AutoVis papers receive large citation and download counts while most receive modest attention. CrossRef citation counts have mean ≈ 31 and median 14 with a long right tail (max ≈ 292), and downloads likewise vary widely (median ≈ 937). Reproducibility signals are weak in the metadata examined: GraphicsReplicabilityStamp is empty for all records in this dataset, even though many papers (≈70% overall and ≈71% of AutoVis candidates) include deployment mentions (code, demos, or datasets) in their metadata. Gaps and opportunities therefore cluster around: (1) evaluation practices — more standardized benchmarks and clearer external evaluations are needed, (2) artifact sharing and replicability signaling — adoption of stamps, artifact badges, and standardized repository practices would improve reuse, and (3) community infrastructure — shared datasets, evaluation frameworks, and curated tool repositories would accelerate progress. Actionable recommendations include adopting and requiring artifact disclosure (or a replication stamp), establishing benchmark tasks and datasets for AutoVis evaluation, promoting mixed-initiative best-practice guidelines and standardized reporting of deployment/implementation, and organizing community sessions (special tracks, challenges, or curated tool repos) to centralize resources.

content.text: The citation-distribution visualization (histogram + CDF) and the Year-versus-citations scatter with LOESS trend communicate impact at both population and per-paper levels. Citation data show a heavy-tail distribution: most papers have citation counts in the low tens, while a small set reaches the hundreds; downloads follow a similar spread (median ≈ 937, mean ≈ 1,246). The scatter plot (citations vs. year) sized by downloads shows older, foundational papers often accumulate more citations but that several recent works (e.g., Voyager 2015, Draco 2018) also achieved strong impact quickly. An attempt to compute Spearman correlation between citations and downloads failed in the automated pipeline (missing SciPy), but visually the scatter suggests a positive relationship with exceptions: high-download or high-citation outliers exist and merit individual inspection. These plots support nuanced impact assessments that couple bibliometrics with artifact and deployment signals rather than relying on raw citation counts alone.

content.text: The GraphicsReplicabilityStamp visualizations confirm a troubling absence of explicit reproducibility metadata: every record in this collection has an empty GraphicsReplicabilityStamp field, yielding 0% coverage across years and conferences. At the same time, many papers include deployment mentions in text or metadata (about 70% coverage overall and varying by venue), suggesting that while authors often publish code or demos, the community has not yet adopted a standardized stamp or badge to surface reproducibility status in bibliographic records. This gap argues for community-level interventions: introduce and promote a simple metadata badge (replicability/artifact-available), require authors to report code/data locations in submission systems, and convene special sessions or reproducibility challenges to raise visibility and reward artifact-sharing.
